trait.name: Every Sense Sharp
entries: The chiminimera gets a bonus to its initiative rolls equal to its Wisdom modifier.

trait.name: Three Heads
entries: The chiminimera has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight, hearing or smell and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded} and {@condition deafened}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The chiminimera makes two attacks: one with its bite, and one with its sting. When its acid breath is available, it can use the breath in place of its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking 5 ({@damage 2d4}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Acid Breath {@recharge}
entries: The snake head exhales acid in a 10-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw, taking 7 ({@damage 3d4}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
One part cuteness, three parts death. The chiminimera lives close to running streams and shallow ponds where it hunts for prey like frogs, fish and small mammals.
Being as vicious as its bigger cousin, this little critter was observed to even overpower significantly larger animals with frightening efficiency, seemingly just for its own amusement.

Most predators know the wicked character of the chiminimera and are wise enough to leave it alone. Evil casters, however, are almost irresistibly attracted to the sheer ferocity of this intriguing creature.
Fragile, but blessed with an unmatched agility and equipped with the sight of a mantis, the chiminimera seems to be nearly impossible to surprise, let alone to catch.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Sight
entries: The copycat has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

trait.name: Light Sensitivity
entries: While in bright light, the copycat has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Shadow-Born
entries: While in dim light or darkness the copycat can take the Disengage or Hide action as a bonus action on each of its turns and has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

trait.name: Grim Connoisseur
entries: The copycat has advantage on ability checks to identify creatures and recall lore about them.

action.name: Hollowing Glimpse
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) necrotic damage. The copycat regains {@dice 1d4} hit points.

action.name: Macabre Mimicry (3/Day)
entries: The copycat targets one Tiny creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be magically absorbed by the copycat. When absorbed, the target dissolves into dark dust and is being digested by the copycat. If the copycat dies while digesting a creature, the absorbed creature reappears in the copycat's space, drops to 1 hit point and is {@condition unconscious}. Otherwise the absorbed creature ceases to exist after 8 hours.

While digesting a creature, the copycat gains all resistances, immunities and special traits of that creature. In addition, the copycat can use that creature's actions and reactions. If special appendages or body modifications are required for any of the features, they appear on the copycat as spectral manifestations representative of the absorbed creature.

Creeping and stalking through the darkness, this nocturnal predator has the most remarkable method of ingestion. Instead of depending on actual food, it feeds on the very essence of other beings, mysteriously absorbing them.

On top of that, the copycat is capable of adopting any skill, trait or other quality of similar-sized creatures unfortunate enough to land in its magical belly. This remarkable feature receives much attention from practitioners of the dark arts. Legend has it that some sinister tinkerer even invented a twisted item strong enough to bind the copycat and harvest its powers...

resist.note: from Nonmagical Attacks that aren't Silvered

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

reaction.name: Charring Gaze
entries: If the crampler is attacked, it can target up to 6 nonmagical objects that it can see within 60 feet of it and magically turns them into coal. If the object is either armor or a shield being worn or carried, its takes a -2 penalty to the AC it offers. After taking damage, the armor or shield made of coal has a 30 percent chance of breaking. If the object is a weapon and before dealing damage, it takes a -2 penalty to damage rolls. After dealing damage, the weapon has a 30 percent chance of breaking.
The effect lasts until removed by the remove curse spell or other magic.

As if life in the frosty wastelands wasn't hard enough already, the crampler makes it even more tedious. Fickle and spiteful, this little fiend is known to haunt small towns for several weeks or even months.
Knowing its untouchable nature, the pesky gadfly usually demands food–with a preference for pastry, fruits or berries–and other conformities such as a warm place to rest.
If treated badly, the short-tempered crampler uses its unsettling gaze to punish those who did it wrong–needless to say, it enjoys to do so...

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (3/Day)
headerEntries: The doppledo can innately cast goodberry, requiring no material components. Its innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence.

trait.name: Two-Headed
entries: The doppledo has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Two-Faced
entries: Each time the doppledo makes an ability check, attacks, casts a spell, or is attacked, it has a 30 percent chance to go feral until the end of its next turn. While feral, the doppledo can't speak or use its Innate Spellcasting, can make one beak attack as a bonus action, and attacks the nearest creature it can see.

action.name: Beak (Feral Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 slashing damage.

Two sides of the same coin, the doopledo is regarded as divine by mothbird culture. One head represents their wisdom and tranquility, while the other one embodies their ferocious and primal heritage. It is said that only the wisest mothbirds seek counsel from the doopledo, potentially risking their lives, as one head constantly overrules the other one. This alternation makes the doopledo either a pleasant adviser or a potentially belligerent beast.
{@b Obliging Counselor}. If not feral, the doppledo is a bountiful adviser, gladly sharing its knowledge about local points of interest and rumors or willingly offering its spellcasting abilities.

monster.name: Droplhorse
languages: understands Aquan and Auran but can't speak

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The droplhorse's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Flocking Luminescence
entries: The droplhorse can choose to shed dim light in a 30-foot radius in a color of its choice, while within 30 feet of another, conscious droplhorse.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The droplhorse can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid suffocating.

trait.name: Underwater Camouflage
entries: The droplhorse has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made while underwater.
A soft glow from primeval times. On rare occasions, the peculiar droplhorse can be observed dancing and fluttering through drizzle and fog.

What makes this human hand-sized creature remarkable is that it excels both at swimming and flying. Especially after heavy rainfall droplhorses seem to dwell near settlements and camps. They are assumed to be lured by flickering lights, as they are sometimes caught putting out candles or similar light sources using their magic tricks.

Classified as a living fossil, many scholars assume that only a few individuals of this wonderous critter are still alive. A school of fluorescent droplhorses painting the sky, however, is described as being an absolutely breathtaking sight to experience.

monster.name: Droplhorse Larva
languages: understands Aquan and Auran but can't speak

trait.name: Jittery Illumination
entries: The larva sheds flickering dim light in a 5-foot radius in random colors. While it is within 20 feet of another, conscious droplhorse, the droplhorse has a +1 bonus to its AC and advantage on Dexterity saving throws.

trait.name: Minor Amphibiousness
entries: The larva can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every 1 hour to avoid suffocating.

action.name: Acid Splatter
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 4} to hit, range 30 ft., one target. {@h}1 acid damage.

action.name: Luminescent Poison {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 20/40 ft., one target. {@h}The larva chooses a color; The target is covered in a thin layer of glowing liquid and sheds dim light of that color in a 5-foot radius and it can't benefit from being {@condition invisible}. In addition, the first time each turn the target takes acid damage, the target takes an extra 1 poison damage.
The layer of liquid lasts until the end of the larva's next turn.

According to scholars, the steady extinction of the droplhorses might–among other reasons–be linked to their slow reproduction rate. If there is any larva at all, it is usually the only one among a group of adult droplhorses.

Despite its little size, it is far from being defenseless and constitutes a more than beneficial addition to the swarm. Already equipped with the bioluminescence of a droplhorse, the larva can alter its chemicals to produce a unique poison making the victim more vulnerable to the adults' attacks.
If not accompanied by a swarm, scattered droplhorse larvas are believed to take shelter in deep coral reefs or dense kelp forests.

trait.name: Fertile Ground (1/Day)
entries: If exposed to water or moisture the droughtoise instantly grows {@dice 1d6} magically infused berries on its shell and head. A creature can use its action to harvest or eat one berry. Eating a berry restores 1 hit point, and the berry provides enough nourishment to sustain a creature for one day. The berries wither after 24 hours or if the droughtoise dies and lose their potency if they have not been consumed within 24 hours after harvesting.

trait.name: Sluggish
entries: The droughtoise has disadvantage on attack rolls and Dexterity saving throws.

trait.name: Soilbound
entries: For each round the droughtoise doesn't touch at least 500 pounds of soil, it takes 1 necrotic damage.

action.name: Shove
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 bludgeoning damage.

Tiny moving desert islands–Slowly roaming through drylands and wastes, this tiny companion has saved more than one lost wanderer from starving. When exposed to even a single drop of water, this wanderer instantly grows a small supply of nutritious berries.
While it obviously gets pretty annoyed, when other creatures harvest its precious crop, the droughtoise can't really do much about it.
While this creature seems like a perfect food supplier, it unfortunately proves to be very delicate, as it needs constant connection to the soil. Otherwise it quickly weakens and ultimately perishes.

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The dustlet can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the dustlet doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The dustlet deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Accelerated Pebble
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 20/40 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Dusty Gust {@recharge 5}
entries: The dustlet targets each Medium or smaller creature and object within 5 feet of it. If the target is a creature, it must make a {@dc 10} Strength saving throw.

On a failure or if the target is an object, the dustlet deals 2 ({@damage 1d4}) bludgeoning damage to the target and the target is flung up 20 feet away from the dustlet in a random direction and knocked {@condition prone}. If a thrown target strikes an object, such as a wall or floor, the target takes 1 bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown. If the target is thrown at a Tiny or Small creature, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or take the same damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.
If the saving throw is successful, the target takes half the bludgeoning damage and isn't flung away or knocked {@condition prone}.

The dustlet is rumored to be one of the many designed creatures developed by the notorious, yet secret Institute of Microzoological Alchemy. Originally bred as tiny living siege engines for close quarter combat, the dustlets soon realized that their power to break in might serve them to break out just as well. What followed was a great escape of most imprisoned species ultimately leading to the downfall of the institute–or at least that's what is officially known.
The dustlet might look innocent–the combined power of earth and air, however, must not be underestimated, as this critter may quickly annihilate unguarded possessions and objects.

trait.name: Figuratively Speaking
entries: The eye catcher conveys ideas and thoughts in the form of abstract images using its telepathy.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The eye catcher has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Swarmish
entries: The eye catcher can move through any opening as narrow as 1 inch wide.

action.name: All Eyes on You
entries: The eye catcher focuses all its eyes on one creature it can see within 15 feet of it, attempting to attack the target's mind. The target makes a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw, taking 7 ({@damage 3d4}) psychic damage and be {@condition blinded} for 1 minute on a failed save, or taking half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Eye-Opener (1/Day)
entries: The eye catcher targets a willing creature it can see within 5 feet of it. If the target has at least one eye, an eye of the target magically pops out of the target's body and becomes part of the eye catcher. The target loses 2 ({@dice 1d4}) hit points and gains proficiency in one skill of its choice in the process. In addition, the eye catcher's hit point maximum is increased by 1. A creature can only ever be targeted by this action once.

"Eye snatcher, eye patcher, hide from the eye catcher."–While this nursery rhyme chanted by children playing hide-and-seek might sound like a harmless pun, this critter is more than just a fairy tale.
No eye looking like the other, the baffling eye catcher–if found at all–is sometimes seen creeping around the outskirts of villages or cities.

It is still unknown whether this apparition is an invisible being controlling a macabre collection of eyes or if these floating and bouncing eyeballs are actually collectively acting individuals. Whatever the truth is, the eye catcher is said to gift knowledge and talent to anyone brave or maybe naive enough to pay the price...

trait.name: Immemorial Memory
entries: The filiodon remembers everything it has ever experienced.

trait.name: Trampling Charge
entries: If the filiodon moves at least 15 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a headbutt attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 1 bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Headbutt
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/30 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage, or 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Primeval and warmhearted–Living in communal camps, the never forgetting filiodon usually settles near fertile hunting grounds, such as shores, forests or steppes. It strives for absolute harmony with nature and therefore only takes what it needs to survive, honoring the spirits of its prey.

One of the filiodon's most remarkable features is its prominent baldness resulting from the numerous headbutting duels it has–a tradition the filiodon literally elevated to an art form. Not only does it exercise headbutting to settle occasional rivalry among individuals but also in greetings, for sports and even in dance routines. In this manner bald visitors are admired as artists of great vigor and commitment, often finding themselves in the position to demonstrate their prowess.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The frost ora's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}, +5 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The frost ora can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) cold damage.
Strongly linked to the arcane, this little critter has successfully mastered even some of the mightier spells and can naturally cast potent ice-related magic.

Since the frost ora draws its energy directly from its inherent powers, it basically doesn't require any kind of food. Therefore most frost oras are found–if at all–snoozing in their narrow lairs deeply burrowed into icy mountains.

trait.name: Hearty Hug
entries: As long as the heartbold is attached to a creature, that creature's lowest ability score is increased by 1. That creature chooses among equally low scores.

trait.name: Love you all
entries: While not attached to a creature, the heartbold must use its Cuddle Attack on each of its turns. If no creature is near enough, the heartbold must use its movement and Dash action on its turn to move toward the nearest creature it can see by the most direct route. The heartbold doesn't avoid opportunity attacks or damaging terrain.

trait.name: Undead Fortitude.
entries: If damage reduces the heartbold to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the heartbold drops to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Undead Nature
entries: A heartbold doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

action.name: Cuddle Attack
entries: The heartbold targets the nearest creature it can see within 5 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 6} Dexterity saving throw or the heartbold is {@condition incapacitated} and attached to it. The target can choose to fail the saving throw. While attached, the heartbold's speed becomes 0, it can't benefit from any bonus to its speed and it moves with the target. A creature, including the target, can detach the heartbold by making a successful {@dc 7} Strength check as an action. The heartbold can't detach itself.
Big feelings on tiny legs. How these little creatures came to be and why they wander the land is an utterly unknown mystery.

Some say a heartbold is filled with the kind fragment of a soul: Maybe a lover's love, the compassion of a wise hunter, a proud warrior's devotion or the gratitude of a blushing artist before the crowd.

Perhaps repulsive at first glance, legend has it, that this strange creature has the ability to convey positive feelings to others, helping them tame their inner weaknesses–the feeble feel a bit stronger, the scared slightly braver and the raddled find a new gleam of hope.
Stumbling upon a Heartbold is quite a rare event though, as they are completely defenseless and often fall prey to animals or monsters.

monster.name: Hermit Drake
languages: understands Common and Draconic but can't speak

trait.name: Greedy and Naive
entries: The hermit drake has disadvantage on Wisdom (Insight) checks, if offered or promised shiny, glittery or colorful objects.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The hermit drake has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight, hearing, or smell.

trait.name: Tiny Shell
entries: The hermit drake can withdraw into its shell as an action. Until it emerges, the hermit drake gains a +1 bonus to AC, and has advantage on Constitution saving throws. While in its shell, the hermit drake is {@condition prone}, its speed is 0 and can't increase, it has disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws, it can't take reactions, and the only action the hermit drake can take is a bonus action to emerge from its shell.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) slashing damage.
A reclusive creature, tiny but with a dragon-like confidence. The hermit drake has the habit to seek out colorful shells–the more striking the better–for shelter and protection.

The shell, however, serves another very important purpose: The hermit drake uses it as a mobile hoard for its treasures. Those "treasures" usually only consist of small pebbles, which sometimes are just slightly shinier or more colorful than ordinary ones. This lack of real fortune even makes a simple copper coin a considerably tempting possession for a hermit drake...

monster.name: Marble-Eye
languages: understands Common plus one other language but can't speak

trait.name: Absolutely Motionless.
entries: The marble-eye can't move and can't benefit from any bonus to its speed. The marble-eye automatically fails Strength and Dexterity saving throws and attack rolls against it have advantage.

trait.name: Draining Aura
entries: Each creature that starts its turn within 90 feet of the marble-eye takes 1 necrotic damage.

trait.name: Doomed for Eternity
entries: If the marble-eye dies, it appears in an unoccupied space within 90 feet of it. The marble-eye has all its hit points restored, and all conditions and afflictions it suffered before its death are removed.

action.name: Left Marble
entries: The marble-eye targets one creature within 90 feet of it. If the target is a creature other than an undead or a construct, the marble-eye conveys a fleeting sensation to it. The left eye of the marble-eye briefly sheds dim light in a 5-foot radius in the process.

action.name: Right Marble
entries: The marble-eye targets one creature within 5 feet of it. The marble-eye conveys everything it has perceived in the last 24 hours to the target and can alter these memories by adding, removing or changing small details. The right eye of the marble-eye briefly sheds dim light in a 5-foot radius and cracks in the process. The crack disappears after 24 hours. The marble-eye can't use this action as long as its right eye is cracked.
All it sees is death and decay.–Usually surrounded by corpses and remains of tiny creatures, the marble-eye lives an existence doomed to solitude.

On the face of it, this pitiful critter shows no signs of emotions or movement and encounters are too rare to explore whether the marble-eye is actually alive or just some cursed puppet. In any case, it is advised to stay well clear of this little creature, as it drains energy and life of everything and everyone surrounding it–be it fauna or flora.
{@b Well-Informed.} A marble-eye is said to be an inexhaustible source of knowledge and secrets.
{@b Constructed Nature.} The marble-eye doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The minitee can hold its breath for 1 hour.

trait.name: Streamlined
entries: While underwater, the minitee has advantage on attack rolls, as well as on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws. In addition, the minitee counts as one size larger when determining its carrying capacity and the weight it can push, drag, or lift while underwater.

action.name: Tusk
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit , reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) slashing damage if the minitee is underwater.

Clumsy on land, graceful in water–as small as it is, the minitee is quite aware of its impressive tusks and knows how to use them. Luckily for most wary water dwellers, the minitee rarely attacks without previously being provoked. In fact this remarkable animal proves to be a loyal albeit independent companion, if treated well and with respect. In this regard, filiodons and shelligans are occasionally observed to use flocks of minitees as beasts of burden for coastal to subaqueous trading routes.

monster.name: Minkling
languages: understands Common and Sylvan but can't speak

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The minkling's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The minkling has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Tactical Positioning
entries: The minkling gains a bonus to its AC equal to its Intelligence modifier.

trait.name: Vigilant Eyes
entries: The minkling doesn't require sleep.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

action.name: Faint Howl {@recharge}
entries: The minkling emits a faint howl. Each hostile creature within 10 feet of it that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition restrained} until the end of the minkling's next turn.
Proud and vigilant, yet elusive. The minkling, often referred to as the tiny king of the undergrowth, is considered to be the opposite of the rummynose.

Lucky adventurers tell stories about this little critter accompanying them safely through the deepest, darkest and spookiest forests. Woodlanders call it the wanderer's guardian spirit and the minkling proved several times to live up to this reputation. This marvelous creature warns kindhearted beings from danger and doesn't shy away to even put itself on the line to defend its protégés.

Usually keeping a safe distance, the minkling distracts potential villains with faint yet forceful howls. The best chance to get its attention and catch a glimpse is with a hand full of berries and only the kindest intentions.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The molehill giant makes two Toe Crusher attacks.

action.name: Dirty Trick
entries: The molehill giant tosses earth to the eyes of a creature within 15 feet. The target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the end of the molehill giant's next turn.

action.name: Toe Crusher
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 bludgeoning damage. If the molehill giant hits the same creature twice with its Toe Crusher attack on its turn, that creature falls {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tooth Breaker
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one {@condition prone} target. {@h}3 ({@dice 1d6}) 3 bludgeoning damage.

If the molehill giant wouldn't speak Giant, it would hardly classify as such. This peculiar creature, however, actually shares even more distinctive features with its bigger cousin than what meets the eye, as it is highly territorial, always hungry and exceptionally aggressive. Luckily the molehill giant's territories are very small–unfortunately this makes it common to encounter several molehill giants within a few feet.
While molehill giants usually spend their days vociferously quarreling with their neighboring kin, they always stand together to bully a greater intruder.
Known for their dirty tricks in combat, most attempts to communicate with them end up with bruises or broken toes.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The mothbird's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Silky Powder {@recharge 5}
entries: A 15-foot-radius cloud of glimmering powder extends out from the mothbird. The powder spreads around corners. Silky Powder has no effect on constructs and undead. All other creatures in that area must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or fall asleep and remain {@condition unconscious} for 1 hour. That creature awakens if it takes damage or another creature takes an action to wake it. On a failed save, the creature must roll a {@dice d6} to determine the effect of Silky Powder:
{@b 1–3}. The target forgets everything that has happened within the last three hours.
{@b 4–5}. The target forgets everything that has happened within the last six hours.
{@b 6}. The target forgets everything that has happened within the last twelve hours.
Secluded, shrouded in mystery, warmhearted. Just a few documented sightings exist of these human finger-sized creatures, dwelling the bone-chilling cold plains and snowy forests.

Unfortunately most of these sightings are from drunk lumberjacks or hunters who got lost in the wild. Nevertheless, all reports have one common denominator: Covered in glimmering powder, all "victims'" woke up near a village along with fuzzy memories. In addition to feeling exceptionally refreshed and energized, they had the strange impression that their wounds seemed to heal much faster than they had before...

trait.name: Root Access
entries: If it has at least 1 hit point, the overflower regains 1 hit point for each scion it controls at the end of each of its turns.

trait.name: Build and Deploy
entries: The overflower summons up to 2 Tiny creatures it knows as its scions. It can't summon another overflower. Each scion appears in an unoccupied space within 15 feet of the overflower. The scion's type is plant, its alignment is lawful evil, it loses any tags, has vulnerability to fire damage and it appears orange-toned. Additionally the scion is under the overflower's control and conveys what it senses to the overflower. The scion dies, if the overflower dies or if it is at least 1 mile away from the overflower.
The overflower can have no more than 4 scions at a time and can destroy a scion at any time. If a scion dies, it crumbles to dust.

reaction.name: Back Up
entries: If the overflower drops to 0 hit points, it destroys one of its scions. The overflower has a 20 percent chance to drop to 1 hit point and to reappear in that scion's space. In addition, all conditions and afflictions it suffers are replaced by those which the scion suffered.
The overflower repeats this process until it successfully reappears or until all of its scions are destroyed.

Townsfolk tell stories about strange sightings of orange-toned critters, accompanied by mysterious, seemingly unrelated incidents: Things reappearing in strange places, people gone missing, small livestock gone mad or odd noises coming from the ground. A scholar might quickly draw the conclusion for the sole reason behind all this: An overflower has set up camp nearby.

Equipped with a puzzling mind, this plant-like creature usually plans its dark schemes from a distance. While an overflower's motives seem incomprehensible and chaotic, it still follows a strict, yet alien logic, sending in its cohort of mind-controlled scions to execute its evil plans.
{@b Biointerface.} An overflower doesn't know any language per se and therefore uses its scions to communicate through them.

trait.name: Copy That
entries: The parrot grub can mimic all sounds and words it heard since its last turn. It can change the pitch of these words and sounds.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The parrot grub has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Pitch Shifter
entries: Creatures within 60 feet of the parrot grub perceive its screech as high-pitched and ear-shattering. Otherwise creatures perceive the screech lower-pitched and more guttural the farther away they are.

action.name: Terrifying Screech
entries: When a creature the parrot grub can see starts or ends its turn within 60 feet of the parrot grub, the parrot grub can emit a loud screech. Each creature within 60 feet of the parrot grub that can hear its screech and that isn't another parrot grub must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or become numb for 1 hour. Until this condition ends, the target has disadvantage on all saving throws, all ability checks and attack rolls.

A harmless little fellow, with a fascinating twist. Bizarre in terms of appearance, it uses a unique defense strategy. When in danger, the parrot grub displays a frightening fake visage while generating high-pitched screeching noises. If heard from a distance, the pitch of those sounds gets significantly lower, giving the false impression of a much bigger, more dangerous creature.

Monster hunters often get lured by these sounds, looking for valuable prey, just to get an unpleasant surprise: When standing close to a threatened parrot grub, the high-pitched screams are described as intimidatingly constricting causing intense nightmares and horrors.

monster.name: Rummynose
languages: understands Common and Sylvan but can't speak

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The rummynose's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The rummynose has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight, hearing, or smell.

trait.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the rummynose can take the Hide action as a bonus action.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The rummynose can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

action.name: Shadow Leap {@recharge 5}
entries: The rummynose teleports up to 20 feet to an unoccupied space it can see that is in dim light or darkness.

It never chases its victims, only edges toward them. Devious and lurking through the canopy of the darkest forests, the rummynose rather observes than engages, always planning its next scheme. Utilizing deceptive tricks and illusion magic, this slow-moving critter lures unsuspecting adventurers into their doom. Be it by leading them into the arms of slumbering monsters, hazardous terrain or old traps–long forgotten by their creators.
The cruel motivation for this behavior is yet to be explored, since the rummynose never seems to show any further interest in their victims once their fate is ultimately sealed...

trait.name: Good Nose
entries: While the snifflewhiff can smell a creature, it has advantage on Wisdom (Insight) checks to determine if the creature is lying.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The snifflewhiff has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight or smell.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The snifflewhiff can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Web Sense
entries: While in contact with a web, the snifflewhiff knows the exact location of any other creature in contact with the same web.

trait.name: Web Walker
entries: The snifflewhiff ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}1 piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 9} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage.

reaction.name: Lie Leech
entries: If the snifflewhiff detects that a creature is telling a lie, it deals 2 ({@damage 1d4}) necrotic damage to that creature. Additionally, until the end of its next turn, the creature can't speak and can't cast a spell that includes a verbal component. The snifflewhiff can't use this reaction if it isn't able to use its sense of smell.
Contorted attics, endlessly winding cellars, obstructed corridors–this is the snifflewhiff's preferred habitat.

Often referred to as "merchant's curse" this creature has the extraordinary ability to smell lies and even more astonishing–feed on them, rendering its victim literally speechless. While this effect only lasts a few seconds, it sometimes doesn't take more time, to ruin a dishonest trader's business.

Naturally, the snifflewhiff settles where lies are dense and deception flourishes. Therefore, most of the very few confirmed encounters originate from highly populated or corrupted urban areas such as trading quarters, dock areas or aristocratic courtyards.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The sparkling has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight, hearing, or smell.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
entries: The sparkling can take the Disengage or Hide action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

reaction.name: Glittery Sparkles (1/Day)
entries: If another creature the sparkling can see, hear, or smell moves within 60 feet of the sparkling, the sparkling exhales a 20-foot-radius cloud of colorful and glittering sparkles extending all around it. The area is heavily obscured until the end of the sparkling next turn. Each humanoid that sees the release of the sparkles feels uplifted and gains 2 ({@dice 1d4}) temporary hit points.
A peculiar little dragon, only emerging once a year from its slumber for its hunt for small insects or similar sized critters.

Easily startled, the sparkling is named after the colorful sparkles it releases to escape potential predators if disturbed. Ironically many folks perceive these sparkles as an uplifting sign for good luck. It is not unusual for locals to celebrate the awakening of the sparklings with sumptuous festivities in honor of this fantastic creature.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The steamlet can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

trait.name: Microclimate
entries: At the start of each of the steamlet's turns, it can choose between a cold aura or a heat aura affecting its space.

entries.name: Cold Aura
entries: Each nonmagical liquid within the aura that isn't being worn or carried freezes. A creature that touches the steamlet or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 1 cold damage.

entries.name: Heat Aura
entries: Each flammable object within the aura that isn't being worn or carried ignites. A creature that touches the steamlet or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 1 fire damage.

action.name: Icicle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage plus 1 cold damage.

action.name: Steam Burst {@recharge}
entries: The steamlet emits freezing and scalding steam. Each creature within 15 feet must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw, taking 2 ({@damage 1d4}) fire damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The steamlet is another species designed by the institute's sinister scientists. Initially developed as a proof of concept to combine elemental fire and water, the implemented overpressure system of the steamlet quickly proved to be a solid tool for combat.

Usually deployed together with dustlets, a steamlet was able to easily overcome any resistance, reliably clearing close quarters from enemies. A tactic the dustlets and steamlets successfully adopted during the great escape from the institute...

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the thistling can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Plant Camouflage
entries: The thistling has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks it makes in any terrain with ample obscuring plant life.

trait.name: Pesky Beast
entries: While attached to a creature, if the thistling makes a successful saving throw against a spell, a spell attack misses it, or a weapon attack misses it, the spell or attack targets that creature instead of the thistling. If the spell forced a saving throw, the new target makes its own save. If the spell was an attack, the attack roll is rerolled against the new target.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Locked Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or the thistling is attached to the target.

While attached to the target, the Thistling can attack no other creature except the target but has advantage on its attack rolls. The Thistling's speed also becomes 0, it can't benefit from any bonus to its speed and it moves with the target.

A creature, including the target, can detach the Thistling by making a successful {@dc 13} strength check as an action. On a failure, the Thistling deals 7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage to the target. On its turn, the Thistling can release its locked bite as a bonus action.
Hard to see, easy to startle. Nearly impossible to distinguish from a plant, the thistling uses camouflage to hide from bigger predators. Not that this seems to be necessary:

If provoked, the thistling falls into a frenzy-like state, completely in accordance with the motto "offense is the best defense". And the last thing adventurers want is a raging thistling  burying its teeth into their skin.–Experience has shown, that once it locks jaws, it doesn't let it go... If you are still looking for a thistling, sun-drenched meadows and fields might be your best bet.

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The thornpike can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the thornpike doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

trait.name: It comes from below
entries: The thornpike and its tentacles can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there and vice versa. The first time the thornpike or a tentacle enters a hostile non-flying creature's space or that creature enters the thornpike's or a tentacle's space on a turn, that creature takes 1 piercing damage.

trait.name: Plant Camouflage
entries: The wood woad has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks it makes in any terrain with ample obscuring plant life

trait.name: Spiky Skin
entries: A tiny creature that touches the thornpike or a tentacle or hits either with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 1 piercing damage.

trait.name: Wormy Decoy
entries: The thornpike can have up to 3 tentacles at a time. Each tentacle can be attacked (AC 10; 1 hit point; immunity to poison and psychic damage). Destroying a tentacle deals no damage to the thornpike. The thornpike can retract a tentacle as a bonus action.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

action.name: Tiny Tentacle
entries: The thornpike extrudes one tentacle in a space within 20 ft. of it. Any hostile tiny beast that can see the tentacle must make a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, if the creature is more than 0 feet away from the tentacle, the creature must use its movement on its turn to move toward the tentacle by the most direct route. It doesn't avoid opportunity attacks, but doesn't have to move into damaging terrain.

Grim looking yet easily overlooked. The pesky thornpike feasts on small animals that have been lured into its toxic spikes using wormlike decoys, rarely, but nevertheless causing significant damage to small livestock.

While this astonishing creature isn't the most dangerous, adventurers are still strongly advised to watch their steps, as the thornpike's sharp spikes are described as being tough enough to penetrate even the thickest soles.
Though incidents are usually not fatal, a large group of these critters may quickly pose a serious threat...

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The thumbstall knight has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Never Back Down
entries: If damage reduces the thumbstall knight to 0 hit points, it makes a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken. On a success, the thumbstall knight drops to 1 hit point instead, but is {@condition prone}.

action.name: Pesky Sword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

reaction.name: Don't Give Up (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If a friendly creature within 30 feet of the thumbstall knight is reduced to 0 hit points by damage and the two of them can see each other, the thumbstall knight can make a {@dc 19} Charisma check. On a success, the creature drops to 1 hit point instead, but is {@condition prone}.

Never judge a book by its cover–or a thumbstall knight by its size. As miniscule as the body of this fabulous being might be, on the inside beats a big heart. Bravery and courage are no foreign words to the thumbstall knight and it's not surprising that this critter is usually encountered traveling far from its home on a quest for valor or honor–even if these quests often seem far too largely scaled for such a tiny hero. Still, against all odds, the thumbstall knight is so inspiringly resilient that he never backs down or gives up.
{@b Friend with the minkling:} minklings share a special bond with the thumbstall knights and often provide them services as trusty mounts and considerate advisers.

monster.name: Tinkerling
languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The tinkerling can innately cast mending, requiring no material components. Its innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence.

trait.name: Bitsy Beacon
entries: The tinkerling can choose to shed bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet using its magic lightbulb. Whenever the tinkerling takes damage or attacks, the lightbulb has a 10 percent chance of breaking and losing its magical ability to shed light. If the lightbulb breaks or is removed, the tinkerling goes berserk. On each of its turns while berserk, the tinkerling attacks the nearest Tiny or Small object it can see, dealing double damage to it. The tinkerling can't remove its lightbulb by itself.

trait.name: Search and Repair
entries: The tinkerling's long jump and high jump are up to 15 feet each, with or without a running start. While falling, if the tinkerling isn't {@condition incapacitated} and uses its wings, it can change the direction it is heading, slow down its descend up to 30 feet per round and takes no falling damage.

trait.name: Tinny Tinkling
entries: The tinkerling constantly emits rattling and squeaking sounds and has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks to be quiet.

action.name: Wiry Hook
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.
Dwelling through abandoned laboratories, secret workshops or ancient cabinets of curiosities the only hint of the tinkerling's creators are the small engravings of serial numbers or initials.

Not able to fly per se, the tinkerling uses a clever spring mechanism to catapult itself into the air to check its surroundings for anything in need of repair. Its most prominent feature–the magically infused lightbulb–not only serves for illuminating dark corridors or pipe systems but also as a way to communicate short messages by blinking and flickering. Never break or remove it though, as this drives the tinkerling crazy and the consequences are unpredictable.
{@b Constructed Nature}. The tinkerling doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: So Tiny
entries: Even when the toothbold is in plain sight, it takes a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom (Perception) check to spot a toothbold that has neither moved on its own nor taken any action.

trait.name: Dental Flipper
entries: While attached to a creature, the toothbold's Strength score increases by 13 and its Dexterity score decreases to 1. Additionally the toothbold has advantage on ability checks and saving throws to remain attached.

trait.name: Strong Jaw
entries: While the toothbold is attached to a creature, that creature deals an extra 1 necrotic damage (included in the attack), when making an unarmed strike using its teeth.

trait.name: Undead Nature
entries: A toothbold doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

action.name: Attention Danger
entries: While attached to a creature, the toothbold deals 1 necrotic damage to that creature and 1 necrotic damage to itself.

action.name: Yuck
entries: The toothbold targets a creature within 5 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 7} Dexterity saving throw or the toothbold is attached to the target's jaw on the inside of the target's mouth. The target can choose to fail the saving throw. While attached, the toothbold's speed becomes 0, it can't benefit from any bonus to its speed, it moves with the target and the only action it can take, is its Attention Danger. Additionally the toothbold has total cover against attacks and other effects originating outside its host. A creature, including the target, can detach the toothbold by making a successful {@dc 14} Strength check as an action. The toothbold can't detach itself.

Aka the „Teethling"–sounds gross, is gross. Children tell fairy tales about a mad necromancer who created the toothbolds as part of a macabre dental prosthesis. After his death a long time ago, those quirky creepers are believed to still roam the land in search for a new host. Well, every legend has a kernel of truth it seems, as this critter is in fact described to symbiotically live in the jaws of other creatures. In return for the provided shelter, the grateful toothbold is rumored to gift some of its inherent dark magic to its protector and seems to grow strongly attached–figuratively and literally.

{@b Grateful Guest.} A toothbold is devoted to the well-being of its host. To warn its host from danger, it calls for attention by inflicting a slight pain–even if it means that it has to hurt itself.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The tröpfchen can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The tröpfchen can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Tough Nature
entries: The tröpfchen doesn't require air, or sleep.

trait.name: Under Pressure
entries: The tröpfchen can change its appearance to match any fluid it knows as a bonus action. This change includes that fluid's color, opacity, shape and viscosity. While the tröpfchen remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from that fluid.

trait.name: Abyssal Pretaste
entries: Any creature that swallows the tröpfchen gets engulfed in a tiny bit of insanity and suffers one level of {@condition exhaustion}. The tröpfchen is destroyed in the process.

action.name: Consume & Multiply
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}1 acid damage. On a hit, and if the target is an object made of organic matter, or a creature other than a construct, an elemental, an ooze or an undead, the tröpfchen has a 50 percent chance to create an exact copy of itself. The copy can appear in any space within 5 feet of the tröpfchen.
A little glance from the hungering abyss. Taken from the deepest depths of the sea as by-catch, the tröpfchen is usually introduced to dry land by accident.

This cup-sized critter often lingers in moist places with easy access to food or any organic substances for that matter. It can be found hiding in market fountains and urban sewers as well as dwelling in ponds or roaming wet meadows.
The slippery tröpfchen–driven by an insatiable hunger–is feared to quickly wreak havoc: It's able to multiply at an enormous rate if well-fed.
Harmless to most humanoids per se, it is still advised to keep an extra eye on food supplies and pets, as the tröpfchen can perfectly imitate fluids to creep up unnoticed.

trait.name: Mucus
entries: Any creature that ends its turn and grapples the twiddletoad or otherwise had direct contact with the twiddletoad's skin during that turn suffers one level of Twiddletoad's Poisoning.

trait.name: Must...Pet
entries: Any humanoid that starts its turn within 30 feet of the twiddletoad and can see it must make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition charmed} by the twiddletoad until its next turn and feels the urge to pet it. The {@condition charmed} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns.

If the {@condition charmed} creature is more than 5 feet away from the twiddletoad, the creature must use its movement and Dash action on its turn to move toward the twiddletoad by the most direct route in order to pet it. It doesn't avoid opportunity attacks, but doesn't have to move into damaging terrain.
If a target's saving throw is successful, the target is immune to the twiddletoad's Must...Pet for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Spore Cloud
entries: A 5-foot-radius cloud of spores extends out from the twiddletoad. The spores spread around corners. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage and suffer one level of Twiddletoad's Poisoning.

A small toxic creature, very feisty in nature. A rare sight and strongly discussed among alchemists, wizards, biologists and suchlike, if it even exists. Nevertheless the twiddletoad is a highly sought after little critter, as its mucus is said to have magical and highly beneficial effects on mental capacities (among the many potentially dangerous side effects which may occur). Rumour has it that the twiddletoad's preferred habitats are moist and gloomy places such as swamps, ravines, caves or similar locations.

{@b Twiddletoad's Poisoning.} A creature suffers the effect of its current level of Twiddletoad's Poisoning as well as all lower levels. Every one minute a creature loses one level of Twiddletoad's Poisoning and its effect. A creature can't get more than 6 levels of Twiddletoad's Poisoning.
1–{@i Everything feels soft and slimy.} All terrain is difficult terrain for the creature.
2–{@i The creature hallucinates shimmering bubbles at the edge of its vision.} The creature has disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.
3–{@i The creature perceives its extremities as mushroom-like.} The creature has disadvantage on ability checks that rely on using its extremities and attack rolls.

4–{@i The creature has difficulties to speak as it can only produce smacking, bubbling sounds.} The creature can't cast a spell that includes a verbal component and has disadvantage on ability checks that rely on speaking.
5–{@i The creature's body feels wonky and fluffy.} At the start and end of each of the creature's turns it falls prone.

6–{@i The creature's mind is clear and it can shape thoughts at will.} The creature has advantage on Intelligence checks that rely on memory, reasoning or imagination and automatically succeeds on Constitution saving throws to maintain its concentration.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Sight
entries: The vamster has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage plus 1 necrotic damage. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.
{@i "You heard right, vamster it is!"}–Those were the last documented words of this remarkable creature's discoverer, before being turned into an empty husk by a swarm of said vamsters.
As cuddly as it may seem at first sight, the vamster is no critter to frivolously mess around with: Not undead, still an inexplicable vampiric hunger is running through its veins.

Usually acting in large packs, this sinister creature lives and travels underground by digging long tunnels through soil and even rock at an incredibly high speed. It only emerges and shows off its flight skills to attack or to feed on prey too large for their underworldly dwellings. The best strategy to escape from a frenzied swarm of vamsters is to drop a bait and hope for the best.

trait.name: Bloodcurdling Squeaks
entries: The swarm constantly emits squeaking and scratching sounds. The swarm has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks. In addition, if a creature starts its turn within 30 feet of the swarm and can hear it, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if it can hear the swarm, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the swarm's Bloodcurdling Squeaking for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Sight
entries: The swarm has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a tiny vamster. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

trait.name: Voraciously Hungry
entries: If the swarm hits a creature with a melee attack, the swarm flies into a biting frenzy and has advantage on the next attack roll against that creature.

trait.name: Yet So Fluffy
entries: If the swarm hits a humanoid or beast with a melee attack, that creature feels a fluffy sensation and must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} by the swarm until the start of the swarm's next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The swarm makes two attacks.

action.name: Bites
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 0 ft., one creature in the swarm's space. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) necrotic damage, or 5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) necrotic damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.
{@i "You heard right, vamster it is!"}–Those were the last documented words of this remarkable creature's discoverer, before being turned into an empty husk by a swarm of said vamsters.
As cuddly as it may seem at first sight, the vamster is no critter to frivolously mess around with: Not undead, still an inexplicable vampiric hunger is running through its veins.

Usually acting in large packs, this sinister creature lives and travels underground by digging long tunnels through soil and even rock at an incredibly high speed. It only emerges and shows off its flight skills to attack or to feed on prey too large for their underworldly dwellings. The best strategy to escape from a frenzied swarm of vamsters is to drop a bait and hope for the best.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Sight
entries: The swarm has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a tiny vamster. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

trait.name: Voraciously Hungry
entries: If the swarm hits a creature with a melee attack, the swarm flies into a biting frenzy and has advantage on the next attack roll against that creature.

action.name: Bites
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 0 ft., one creature in the swarm's space. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) necrotic damage, or 1 piercing damage plus 1 necrotic damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.
{@i "You heard right, vamster it is!"}–Those were the last documented words of this remarkable creature's discoverer, before being turned into an empty husk by a swarm of said vamsters.
As cuddly as it may seem at first sight, the vamster is no critter to frivolously mess around with: Not undead, still an inexplicable vampiric hunger is running through its veins.

Usually acting in large packs, this sinister creature lives and travels underground by digging long tunnels through soil and even rock at an incredibly high speed. It only emerges and shows off its flight skills to attack or to feed on prey too large for their underworldly dwellings. The best strategy to escape from a frenzied swarm of vamsters is to drop a bait and hope for the best.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Sight
entries: The swarm has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a tiny vamster. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

trait.name: Voraciously Hungry
entries: If the swarm hits a creature with a melee attack, the swarm flies into a biting frenzy and has advantage on the next attack roll against that creature.

trait.name: Yet So Fluffy
entries: If the swarm hits a humanoid or beast with a melee attack, that creature feels a fluffy sensation and must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} by the swarm until the start of the swarm's next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The swarm makes two attacks.

action.name: Bites
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 0 ft., one creature in the swarm's space. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) necrotic damage, or 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage plus 1 necrotic damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.
{@i "You heard right, vamster it is!"}–Those were the last documented words of this remarkable creature's discoverer, before being turned into an empty husk by a swarm of said vamsters.
As cuddly as it may seem at first sight, the vamster is no critter to frivolously mess around with: Not undead, still an inexplicable vampiric hunger is running through its veins.

Usually acting in large packs, this sinister creature lives and travels underground by digging long tunnels through soil and even rock at an incredibly high speed. It only emerges and shows off its flight skills to attack or to feed on prey too large for their underworldly dwellings. The best strategy to escape from a frenzied swarm of vamsters is to drop a bait and hope for the best.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The vermingeist can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Ethereal Wanderer
entries: The vermingeist can see 30 ft. into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane, and vice versa. Additionally the the vermingeist can use its bonus action to magically shift from the Material Plane to the Ethereal Plane, or vice versa. If the vermingeist touches a Tiny creature or a Tiny object in the process, that creature or object shifts to the according plane as well.

trait.name: Warped Masquerade
entries: If another vermingeist dies within 30 ft. of the vermingeist, the vermingeist must use its reaction to take of its mask to mourn. If the vermingeist starts its turn without wearing a mask, each non-undead creature within 30 feet of the vermingeist that can see it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw, taking 5 ({@damage 2d4}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The vermingeist must use its next action to put on its mask again.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The vermingeist has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight, hearing, or smell.

action.name: Ghostly Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 necrotic damage.

If anything disappears as if by magic, it was–well sometimes actual magic or worse–the vermingeist. Although not relying on food per se, groups of vermingeists reach out from the Ethereal plain to raid pantries, storage rooms or warehouses. Allegedly cursed with a dreadful visage, this tiny being always wears a mask made from skulls of similarly sized creatures. These masks are handed down within the pack and are only taken off to mourn over a kindred's death for the very few seconds before the corpse turns into a fleeting mist.
{@b Undead Nature.} A vermingeist doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The woolpertinger has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight, hearing, or smell.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
entries: The woolpertinger can take the Disengage or Hide action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Smooth Moves
entries: Attack rolls against the woolpertinger have disadvantage unless the woolpertinger is {@condition incapacitated} or {@condition restrained}. In addition, the woolpertinger has advantage on ability checks and saving throws made to escape from restraints or being {@condition grappled}.

trait.name: Snow-Born
entries: The woolpertinger has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in snowy terrain. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra moment.

action.name: Frosty Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit , reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or, for 1 minute, its speed is reduced by 10 feet.

reaction.name: Elusive Blink
entries: When the woolpertinger takes damage, it can teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.

A creature so elusive that many people even doubt its very existence. Sightings are yet to confirm and "evidence" usually turns out to be either replicas or macabre works of fraudulent taxidermists looking for easy recognition.

Old folks ramble about woolpertingers roaming through the snowiest outlands and some even tell tales of tamed individuals used as secret messengers or thieves pets. The truth behind these stories, however, remains shrouded in mystery–just like the woolpertinger itself.
